block.p: New Proof That Microsoft Plays Role in Linux Fight More evidence is emerging about Microsoft's role in encouraging the anti-Linux campaign being waged by the SCO Group.

BayStar Capital said that Microsoft suggested it invest in SCO, which is engaged in a legal campaign against Linux, a rival to Microsoft's Windows. BayStar did so, investing $50 million in SCO last October. [Page C5.]

A Look at Shell's Reserve Policy Internal corporate documents and interviews with oil executives and industry analysts describe how the Royal Dutch/Shell Group tried to manage its reserve figures to satisfy investors in Europe and the United States. [A1.]

Imprecise regulations, geological guesswork and corporate culture are some of the reasons given to explain why companies can suddenly report far fewer potential oil and gas reserves than they initially stated. [C4.]

Earnings Increase 11% at Oracle Oracle reported an 11 percent increase in third-quarter profit and a 9 percent jump in revenue, driven by strong sales of its database products. Oracle executives predicted technology spending would continue to improve this year. Wall Street views Oracle's earnings as an indicator of the software industry because the company announces earnings a month before its rivals. [C5.]

Manufacturing Nominee Withdraws President Bush's nominee for manufacturing czar, Anthony F. Raimondo, withdrew from consideration, 24 hours after Senator John Kerry criticized him for laying off American workers and opening a factory in China. [A18.]
Fed Chairman Supports Free Trade Alan Greenspan waded deeper into the political battle over jobs and trade by warning Congress not to create trade barriers. [C6.]
S.E.C. Strengthens Accounting The Securities and Exchange Commission changed its rules to encourage foreign companies, particularly European ones, to adopt international accounting standards. [C6.]

Canada to Curb Auto Emissions The environment minister of Canada said that his country would emulate California's new law aimed at curbing automotive global warming emissions if carmakers did not agree to make significant reductions. [C4.]

Puma Becomes a Leader Ten years ago, Puma was on the brink of bankruptcy, struggling under eight years of losses, $250 million in debt, and a warehouse filled with 1.5 million pairs of cheap $10 sneakers. Now, Puma is profitable for the 10th consecutive year, bolstered by sales of its stylish $90 Mostro, a suede designer shoe. The turnaround has been led by Jochen Zeitz, who became chief executive of Puma in March 1993 at the age of 29. [World Business, Section W.]

House Backs Programming Fines Saying that much of the public is fed up with indecent television and radio programming, members of the House voted overwhelmingly to increase penalties on broadcasters and performers who violate federal standards. [A12.]
4 Designers to Replace a Star Tom Ford, the design star whom many in the fashion industry considered irreplaceable, will be succeeded by four unknown designers at Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent. [C6.]
EchoStar and Viacom End Dispute EchoStar Communications resolved a contract dispute with Viacom, restoring 16 CBS stations and 10 national cable channels to millions of viewers. [C2.]

Stocks Continue to Decline Stocks declined with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dipped 17.11 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,106.78, placing it in negative territory for the year. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 168.51 points, to 10,128.38, and the Nasdaq composite slipped 20.26 points, to 1,943.89. [C6.]
